user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarUnlock:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarUnlock(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarUnlock:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No pointer declarations in the provided code appear to violate MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13. Reasons: 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t, osal_objtype_t, osal_id_t, OS_object_token_t *token) takes token as a non-const pointer because it is an output/modified parameter (token->obj_idx and token->obj_id are assigned). Making this parameter const would prevent the required modifications.

- The local variable token in OS_CondVarUnlock is a non-const object because it is populated by OS_ObjectIdGetById. It cannot be declared const for the same reason.

- OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl accepts const OS_object_token_t *token (already const-qualified), which follows the guideline for input-only pointers.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken is declared to take const OS_object_token_t *token (correct for read-only use).

- The OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl pointer in OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl must be non-const because the code calls pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->mut), which modifies the mutex object; making impl (or impl->mut) const would be incorrect.

- Other internal functions called (OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel) are passed token or token member addresses for mutation; those parameters must be non-const.

Given the roles of these pointers (input vs output) and the operations performed (mutating token fields and the mutex), there are no pointers that could be safely and correctly changed to point to const-qualified types in the supplied fragments.
